In recent years, feedback-based fuzzing (or coverage-guided fuzzing) has experienced an unmatched success story. For example, over 27,000 bugs have been found in Chrome and several open-source projects and Google stated that it finds around 80% of its bugs with modern fuzzing techniques. However, fuzzing is not only reserved for the big tech companies but is gradually finding its way into the wide world.
 Fuzzing is used for security and stability testing of the codebase. The application under test is fed with a series of inputs, which are smartly mutated in the testing process. The testing tool gets feedback about the code covered during the execution of inputs. Unlike traditional or black-box fuzzing, feedback-based fuzzing explores the program state efficiently and discovers bugs hidden deep in the code. If you want to learn more in detail about the underlying technology we recommend you to read the blog post  The Magic Behind Feedback-based Fuzzing.

Full-Text Search is one of those tools people use every day without realizing it. If you ever googled "golang coverage report" or tried to find "indoor wireless camera" on an e-commerce website, you used some kind of full-text search.
 Full-Text Search (FTS) is a technique for searching text in a collection of documents. A document can refer to a web page, a newspaper article, an email message, or any structured text.
 Today we are going to build our own FTS engine. By the end of this post, we'll be able to search across millions of documents in less than a millisecond. We'll start with simple search queries like "give me all documents that contain the word  cat" and we'll extend the engine to support more sophisticated boolean queries.
 Most well-known FTS engine is  Lucene (as well as  Elasticsearch and Solr built on top of it).
 Before we start writing code, you may ask "can't we just use  grep or have a loop that checks if every document contains the word I'm looking for?". Yes, we can. However, it's not always the best idea.
 We are going to search a part of the abstract of English Wikipedia. The latest dump is available at  dumps.wikimedia.org. As of today, the file size after decompression is 913 MB. The XML file contains over 600K documents.
  <title>Wikipedia: Kit-Cat Klock </title> <url>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kit-Cat_Klock </url> <abstract>The Kit-Cat Klock is an art deco novelty wall clock shaped like a grinning cat with cartoon eyes that swivel in time with its pendulum tail. </abstract>
 First, we need to load all the documents from the dump. The built-in  encoding/xml package comes very handy:
 import  (  "encoding/xml"  "os" ) type  document  struct  {  Title  string  `xml:"title"`  URL  string  `xml:"url"`  Text  string  `xml:"abstract"`  ID  int } func  loadDocuments ( path  string )  ([] document ,  error )  {  f ,  err  :=  os . Open ( path )  if  err  !=  nil  {  return  nil ,  err  }  defer  f . Close ()  dec  :=  xml . NewDecoder ( f )  dump  :=  struct  {  Documents  [] document  `xml:"doc"`  }{}  if  err  :=  dec . Decode ( & dump );  err  !=  nil  {  return  nil ,  err  }  docs  :=  dump . Documents  for  i  :=  range  docs  {  docs [ i ]. ID  =  i  }  return  docs ,  nil }
 Every loaded document gets assigned a unique identifier.To keep things simple, the first loaded document gets assigned ID=0, the second ID=1 and so on.
 Now that we have all documents loaded into memory, we can try to find the ones about cats. At first, let's loop through all documents and check if they contain the substring  cat:
 func  search ( docs  [] document ,  term  string )  [] document  {  var  r  [] document  for  _ ,  doc  :=  range  docs  {  if  strings . Contains ( doc . Text ,  term )  {  r  =  append ( r ,  doc )  }  }  return  r }
 On my laptop, the search phase takes 103ms - not too bad.If you spot check a few documents from the output, you may notice that the function matches  caterpillar and  category, but doesn't match  Cat with the capital  C. That's not quite what I was looking for.
  Match on a word boundary rather than on a substring (so  caterpillar and  communication don't match).
 One solution that quickly comes to mind and allows implementing both requirements is  regular expressions.
  \b matches a word boundary (position where one side is a word character and another side is not a word character)
 func  search ( docs  [] document ,  term  string )  [] document  {  re  :=  regexp . MustCompile ( `(?i)\b`  +  term  +  `\b` )  // Don't do this in production, it's a security risk. term needs to be sanitized.  var  r  [] document  for  _ ,  doc  :=  range  docs  {  if  re . MatchString ( doc . Text )  {  r  =  append ( r ,  doc )  }  }  return  r }
 Ugh, the search took more than 2 seconds. As you can see, things started getting slow even with 600K documents. While the approach is easy to implement, it doesn't scale well. As the dataset grows larger, we need to scan more and more documents. The time complexity of this algorithm is linear - the number of documents required to scan is equal to the total number of documents. If we had 6M documents instead of 600K, the search would take 20 seconds. We need to do better than that.
 To make search queries faster, we'll preprocess the text and build an index in advance.
 The core of FTS is a data structure called  Inverted Index.The Inverted Index associates every word in documents with documents that contain the word.
  documents  =  {  1 :  "a donut on a glass plate" ,  2 :  "only the donut" ,  3 :  "listen to the drum machine" , } index  =  {  "a" :  [ 1 ],  "donut" :  [ 1 ,  2 ],  "on" :  [ 1 ],  "glass" :  [ 1 ],  "plate" :  [ 1 ],  "only" :  [ 2 ],  "the" :  [ 2 ,  3 ],  "listen" :  [ 3 ],  "to" :  [ 3 ],  "drum" :  [ 3 ],  "machine" :  [ 3 ], }
 Below is a real-world example of the Inverted Index. An index in a book where a term references a page number:
 Before we start building the index, we need to break the raw text down into a list of words (tokens) suitable for indexing and searching.
 The tokenizer is the first step of text analysis. Its job is to convert text into a list of tokens. Our implementation splits the text on a word boundary and removes punctuation marks:
 func  tokenize ( text  string )  [] string  {  return  strings . FieldsFunc ( text ,  func ( r  rune )  bool  {  // Split on any character that is not a letter or a number.  return  ! unicode . IsLetter ( r )  &&  ! unicode . IsNumber ( r )  }) }
 >  tokenize ( "A donut on a glass plate. Only the donuts." ) [ "A" ,  "donut" ,  "on" ,  "a" ,  "glass" ,  "plate" ,  "Only" ,  "the" ,  "donuts" ]
 In most cases, just converting text into a list of tokens is not enough. To make the text easier to index and search, we'll need to do additional normalization.
 In order to make the search case-insensitive, the lowercase filter converts tokens to lower case.  cAt,  Cat and  caT are normalized to  cat.Later, when we query the index, we'll lower case the search terms as well. This will make the search term  cAt match the text  Cat.
 func  lowercaseFilter ( tokens  [] string )  [] string  {  r  :=  make ([] string ,  len ( tokens ))  for  i ,  token  :=  range  tokens  {  r [ i ]  =  strings . ToLower ( token )  }  return  r }
 >  lowercaseFilter ([] string { "A" ,  "donut" ,  "on" ,  "a" ,  "glass" ,  "plate" ,  "Only" ,  "the" ,  "donuts" }) [ "a" ,  "donut" ,  "on" ,  "a" ,  "glass" ,  "plate" ,  "only" ,  "the" ,  "donuts" ]
 Almost any English text contains commonly used words like  a,  I,  the or  be. Such words are called  stop words. We are going to remove them since almost any document would match the stop words.
 There is no "official" list of stop words. Let's exclude the top 10 by the  OEC rank. Feel free to add more:
 var  stopwords  =  map [ string ] struct {}{  // I wish Go had built-in sets.  "a" :  {},  "and" :  {},  "be" :  {},  "have" :  {},  "i" :  {},  "in" :  {},  "of" :  {},  "that" :  {},  "the" :  {},  "to" :  {}, } func  stopwordFilter ( tokens  [] string )  [] string  {  r  :=  make ([] string ,  0 ,  len ( tokens ))  for  _ ,  token  :=  range  tokens  {  if  _ ,  ok  :=  stopwords [ token ];  ! ok  {  r  =  append ( r ,  token )  }  }  return  r }
 >  stopwordFilter ([] string { "a" ,  "donut" ,  "on" ,  "a" ,  "glass" ,  "plate" ,  "only" ,  "the" ,  "donuts" }) [ "donut" ,  "on" ,  "glass" ,  "plate" ,  "only" ,  "donuts" ]
 Because of the grammar rules, documents may include different forms of the same word.Stemming reduces words into their base form. For example,  fishing,  fished and  fisher may be reduced to the base form (stem)  fish.
 Implementing a stemmer is a non-trivial task, it's not covered in this post. We'll take one of the  existing modules:
 import  snowballeng  "github.com/kljensen/snowball/english" func  stemmerFilter ( tokens  [] string )  [] string  {  r  :=  make ([] string ,  len ( tokens ))  for  i ,  token  :=  range  tokens  {  r [ i ]  =  snowballeng . Stem ( token ,  false )  }  return  r }
  A stem is not always a valid word. For example, some stemmers may reduce  airline to  airlin.
 func  analyze ( text  string )  [] string  {  tokens  :=  tokenize ( text )  tokens  =  lowercaseFilter ( tokens )  tokens  =  stopwordFilter ( tokens )  tokens  =  stemmerFilter ( tokens )  return  tokens }
  >  analyze ( "A donut on a glass plate. Only the donuts." ) [ "donut" ,  "on" ,  "glass" ,  "plate" ,  "only" ,  "donut" ]
 Back to the inverted index. It maps every word in documents to document IDs.The built-in  map is a good candidate for storing the mapping.The key in the map is a token (string) and the value is a list of document IDs:
  Building the index consists of analyzing the documents and adding their IDs to the map:
 func  ( idx  index )  add ( docs  [] document )  {  for  _ ,  doc  :=  range  docs  {  for  _ ,  token  :=  range  analyze ( doc . Text )  {  ids  :=  idx [ token ]  if  ids  !=  nil  &&  ids [ len ( ids ) - 1 ]  ==  doc . ID  {  // Don't add same ID twice.  continue  }  idx [ token ]  =  append ( ids ,  doc . ID )  }  } } func  main ()  {  idx  :=  make ( index )  idx . add ([] document {{ ID :  1 ,  Text :  "A donut on a glass plate. Only the donuts." }})  idx . add ([] document {{ ID :  2 ,  Text :  "donut is a donut" }})  fmt . Println ( idx ) }
 It works! Each token in the map refers to IDs of the documents that contain the token:
 To query the index, we are going to apply the same tokenizer and filters we used for indexing:
 func  ( idx  index )  search ( text  string )  [][] int  {  var  r  [][] int  for  _ ,  token  :=  range  analyze ( text )  {  if  ids ,  ok  :=  idx [ token ];  ok  {  r  =  append ( r ,  ids )  }  }  return  r }
 >  idx . search ( "Small wild cat" ) [[ 24 ,  173 ,  303 ,  ... ],  [ 98 ,  173 ,  765 ,  ... ],  [[ 24 ,  51 ,  173 ,  ... ]]
 And finally, we can find all documents that mention cats. Searching 600K documents took less than a millisecond (18µs)!
 With the inverted index, the time complexity of the search query is linear to the number of search tokens. In the example query above, other than analyzing the input text,  search had to perform only three map lookups.
 The query from the previous section returned a disjoined list of documents for each token.What we normally expect to find when we type  small wild cat in a search box is a list of results that contain  small,  wild and  cat at the same time. The next step is to compute the set intersection between the lists. This way we'll get a list of documents matching all tokens.
  Luckily, IDs in our inverted index are inserted in ascending order. Since the IDs are sorted, it's possible tocompute the intersection between two lists in linear time. The  intersection function iterates two lists simultaneously and collect IDs that existin both:
 func  intersection ( a  [] int ,  b  [] int )  [] int  {  maxLen  :=  len ( a )  if  len ( b )  >  maxLen  {  maxLen  =  len ( b )  }  r  :=  make ([] int ,  0 ,  maxLen )  var  i ,  j  int  for  i  <  len ( a )  &&  j  <  len ( b )  {  if  a [ i ]  <  b [ j ]  {  i ++  }  else  if  a [ i ]  >  b [ j ]  {  j ++  }  else  {  r  =  append ( r ,  a [ i ])  i ++  j ++  }  }  return  r }
 Updated  search analyzes the given query text, lookups tokens and computes the set intersection between lists of IDs:
 func  ( idx  index )  search ( text  string )  [] int  {  var  r  [] int  for  _ ,  token  :=  range  analyze ( text )  {  if  ids ,  ok  :=  idx [ token ];  ok  {  if  r  ==  nil  {  r  =  ids  }  else  {  r  =  intersection ( r ,  ids )  }  }  else  {  // Token doesn't exist.  return  nil  }  }  return  r }
 The Wikipedia dump contains only two documents that match  small,  wild and  cat at the same time:
 >  idx . search ( "Small wild cat" ) 130764  The  wildcat  is  a  species  complex  comprising  two  small  wild  cat  species ,  the  European  wildcat  ( Felis  silvestris )  and  the  African  wildcat  ( F .  lybica ). 131692  Catopuma  is  a  genus  containing  two  Asian  small  wild  cat  species ,  the  Asian  golden  cat  ( C .  temminckii )  and  the  bay  cat .
  By the way, this is the first time I hear about  catopuma, here is one of them:
 We just built a Full-Text Search engine. Despite its simplicity, it can be a solid foundation for more advanced projects.
 I didn't touch on a lot of things that can significantly improve the performance and make the engine more user friendly.Here are some ideas for further improvements:
 Experiment with memory and CPU-efficient data formats for storing sets of document IDs. Take a look at  Roaring Bitmaps.

4综述：尽管网速有所提高，但网页速度并没有随着时间的推移而提高。
23年前，互联网与我们今天使用的互联网截然不同。谷歌当时还不存在，只有不到20%的美国家庭有互联网接入，而那些有互联网接入的家庭正在使用拨号连接。
难怪人们抱怨我们当时测试的每个网站的速度都很慢，因为互联网和用来访问它的计算机都慢得令人痛苦。
令人惊讶的是，尽管今天的网速和计算机处理器要快得多，但今天使用互联网的人仍然受到完全相同的挫败感的困扰：网站速度慢。
你可能会想，是不是人们根本没有注意到今天的网站有多快，因为他们的期望值随着时间的推移而增加了。虽然人们对等待时间的估计有时确实被夸大了，但在这种情况下，这不仅仅是一个扭曲的看法问题。
在过去的10年里，Httparchive.org记录了600万个热门网站的页面加载次数。(Httparchive.org是InternetArchive.org的一部分，您可能知道他们是WayBack机器的幕后黑手)。结果并不令人振奋：对于从台式计算机访问的网页，加载时间的中位数并没有改善。今天的网站并不比10年前快多少。
正如你可能猜到的那样，移动端的情况更糟--连接速度确实提高了，但在过去的10年里，Httparchive追踪的移动页面加载时间实际上增加了。
网速的提高显然没有解决网站速度慢的问题。当然，网络速度并不是影响性能的唯一因素，因此期望速度与网络连接完全同步是不合理的。但看起来网络速度的大幅提高至少应该会让浏览网页变得更快一些。
您可能想知道这个数据是否真的准确，这是一个合理的问题，因为有许多不同的方法来衡量性能和速度，例如通过采样不同的网站选择或使用不同的里程碑来确定页面何时加载。例如，2018年，谷歌报告手机页面加载折叠以上内容的平均时间为7秒。但是，由于无法获得10年前的超额加载时间，因此我们不能就该特定指标的趋势得出结论。在任何情况下，即使是这个更有利的数字，仍然比推荐的网页导航响应时间慢7倍。)。Httparchive.org的数据是独一无二的，因为它是在整个十年中使用相同的方法收集的，允许进行纵向比较。这些数据有力地表明，今天人们浏览的网站并不比十年前快多少。
人类感知时间的基本规则为理解网页延迟的影响提供了一个框架：人们可以察觉到短至十分之一秒的延迟，因此任何花费较长时间的事情都不会感觉到“瞬间”。仅仅1秒的延迟就足以中断一个人的有意识的思维过程，把体验变成等待系统跟上，而不是感觉像是你在直接控制界面。此延迟会降低转换率。
我们已经描述了这些仅仅几秒钟的延迟是如何严重影响那些试图使用网站的人的体验的。但你不必相信我们的话-在过去的10年里，缓慢加载的网页对网站废弃和转换的影响已经被一次又一次地证明：
2009年：Google和Bing都报告说，即使加载时间延迟半秒，也会导致转换指标(搜索次数和每个用户的收入)明显降低。
2010年：Mozilla的一项实验发现，将页面加载时间减少2秒会使转化率提高15%。
2011年：Gomez报告了150个站点的1.5亿页面浏览量，发现需要6秒加载的页面比2秒加载的页面被放弃的可能性高出25%。
2016年：谷歌发现，将其SERP的加载时间增加半秒会导致弹跳率增加20%。
2016年：谷歌发现，如果页面加载时间超过3秒，53%的移动访问就会结束。
2017年：Akamai汇总了17家零售商的数据(70亿页面浏览量)，发现加载时间少于2秒的页面转换率最高；加载时间越长，转换率下降50%，跳出率就越高，尤其是对移动访问者而言。
2018年：BBC发现，页面加载时间每增加一秒，就会有10%的用户离开。
2024年：只是开个玩笑，但我们确信，未来会有更多令人信服的数据点添加到这个列表中，因为这个问题不会消失。
如果您仍然不相信响应时间在您的特定行业或较小的组织中很重要，请查看WPOStats.com的这组案例研究，其中记录了性能优化如何显著提高许多不同类型的网站和行业的流量、销售额和使用率指标。
所有这些数据仍然不能准确地定义一个神奇的数字，即你的网站“足够快”还是“太慢”。
如果你是被熊追赶的一群人中的一员，你只需要比这群人中跑得最慢的人快就行了。但网站不是这样运作的：在平均网站速度慢得令人沮丧的情况下，比至少一个其他网站快，甚至比“一般”网站快，这并不是一个伟大的成就。
亚秒级的加载时间将是理想的；实际上，在提供丰富且引人入胜的内容的同时实现这一目标是极其困难的。但是，如果有一件事已经在上面列出的所有实验中得到了充分的证明，那就是速度的每一次增量提高都是有回报的。与其满足于“足够快”，在性能优化方面的投资应该通过这样的问题来推动：“如果我们快1秒，我们会取得多大的成功？”将页面加载时间减少哪怕只有一秒，都会改善用户体验，并提高转换率。你的网站越慢，你就越能从更快的网站中获益。
Cable.co.uk，“全球宽带速度联盟”报道。(此数据是下载速度，而不是Akamai报告的2010年至2017年的连接速度，因此相对于Akamai数据略有夸大)https://www.cable.co.uk/broadband/speed/worldwide-speed-league/
移动分析公司OpenSignal.com，《2019年移动网络体验状况》报告，https://www.opensignal.com/reports/2019/05/global-state-of-the-mobile-network。

4    Summary: In spite of an increase in Internet speed, webpage speeds have not improved over time.
    23 years ago, the internet was quite different from the one we use today. Google didn’t exist yet, fewer than 20% of U.S. households  had internet access, and those who did were using a  dial-up connection.
 It’s no wonder that  people complained about slow speeds on every website we tested back then, because the internet and the computers used to access it were painfully slow.
 What  is surprising is that, despite today’s much faster network speeds and computer processors, people using the internet today are still plagued by the exact same frustration: slow websites.
  You might be wondering whether people simply don’t notice how much faster today’s sites are because their expectations have increased over time. While it’s true that people’s estimates of wait times are sometimes exaggerated, in this case it’s not just a matter of distorted perceptions.
 For the past 10 years,  Httparchive.org has recorded page load times for 6 million popular websites. (Httparchive.org is a part of the InternetArchive.org, whom you may know as the folks behind the WayBack Machine). The results are not encouraging: for webpages visited from a desktop computer, the median load time hasn’t improved.  Today’s websites aren’t that much faster than they were 10 years ago.
  As you might guess, the story on mobile is even worse — connection speeds have improved for sure, but, over the past 10 years, the mobile page load times tracked by Httparchive have actually  increased.
  Increases in internet speed clearly haven’t solved the problem of slow websites. Of course, network speed is not the only factor that affects performance, so it’s not reasonable to expect speeds to have completely kept pace with network connectivity. But it seems like huge increases in network speed should make it at least  somewhat faster to browse the web.
 You may be wondering if this data is really accurate, which is a fair question, as there are many different ways to measure performance and speed, such as by sampling different selections of websites or using different milestones to identify when a page is loaded. For example, in  2018, Google reported an average time of 7 seconds for mobile pages to load content above the fold. But, since above-the-fold loading times from 10 years ago aren’t available, we can’t draw conclusions about trends in that particular metric. In any case, even this more favorable number is still 7 times slower than the recommended response time for navigating web pages.) The Httparchive.org data is unique in that it’s been  collected using the same approach for the entire decade, allowing longitudinal comparison. This data strongly suggests that the websites people encounter today  aren’t that much faster than they were a decade ago.
  The basic  rules of human perception of time provide a framework for understanding the effects of webpage delays: people can detect delays as short as 1/10th of a second, so anything that takes longer doesn’t feel ‘instant.’  Delays of just  1 second are enough to interrupt a person’s conscious thought process, changing the experience into one of waiting for the system to catch up, rather than feeling as though you are directly controlling the interface. This delay reduces  conversion.
 We’ve described how these  delays of just a few seconds seriously hurt the experience of those trying to use a website. But you don’t have to take our word for it — in the past 10 years, the effects of slow-loading web pages on site abandonment and conversion has been proven time and again:
 2009:  Google and  Bing both reported that even half-second delays in load time resulted in measurably lower conversion metrics (number of searches and revenue per user).
  2010: A  Mozilla experiment which found that reducing the page load time by 2 seconds led to 15% higher conversion.
  2011:  Gomez reported on 150M pageviews across 150 sites and found that pages that took 6 seconds to load were 25% more likely to be abandoned than pages which loaded in 2 seconds.
  2016:  Google found that increasing the load time of its SERPs by half a second resulted in a 20% higher bounce rate.
  2016:  Google found 53% of mobile visits ended if a page took longer than  3 seconds to load.
  2017:  Akamai aggregated data from 17 retailers (7 billion pageviews) and found that conversion rates were highest for pages that loaded in less than 2 seconds; longer load times correlated with 50% drops in conversion rates and increased bounce rates, especially for mobile visitors.
  2018:  BBC found that for every extra second of page load time, 10% of users will leave.
  2024: just kidding, but we’re sure there will be many more compelling data points to add to this list in the future, because this problem won’t go away.
 If you’re still not convinced that response time matters in your specific industry or for smaller organizations, check out this  collection of case studies by WPOStats.com, which documents how performance optimization dramatically improves traffic, sales, and usage metrics across many different types of websites and industries.
  All this data still does not precisely define a magic number at which  your site is ‘fast enough’ or ‘too slow.’
 If you’re in a group of people being chased by a bear, you only need to be faster than the slowest person in the group. But that’s not how websites work: being faster than at least one other website, or even faster than the ‘average’ website, is not a great achievement when the average website speed is frustratingly slow.
 Subsecond load times would be ideal; realistically, this target is incredibly difficult to achieve while also delivering rich and engaging content. But, if there’s one thing that’s been amply proven in all the experiments listed above, it’s that each incremental improvement in speed pays off. Instead of settling for being ‘fast enough,’ investment in performance optimization should be driven by asking, ‘how much more successful would we be if we were 1 second faster?’  Reducing page load times by even a second, will improve your users’ experience, and increase your   conversion rates. The slower your website is, the more you have to gain from making it faster.
  Cable.co.uk, “Worldwide Broadband Speed League” reports. (This data is download speed rather than the connectivity speed reported by Akamai for 2010-2017, so is slightly inflated relative to the Akamai data)  https://www.cable.co.uk/broadband/speed/worldwide-speed-league/
  Opensignal.com, a mobile analytics company, “The State of Mobile Network Experience” 2019 report,  https://www.opensignal.com/reports/2019/05/global-state-of-the-mobile-network
  Opensignal.com, a mobile analytics company, “The State of Wifi vs. Mobile Network Experience as 5G Arrives”,  https://www.opensignal.com/reports/2018/11/global-state-of-the-mobile-network

相反，您的日历应该是允许列表。你应该说“如果你想和我说话，这是你可以的时候”，而不是“这是你不能的时候”。你不应该为我们的时间辩护，好像它是黄金，你的同事是海盗。你应该假设你可以按照自己认为合适的方式消费。
有些人阻止休假，试图保护他们的日历。他们在日历上创建了很大的“GTD”区块，并希望没有人在上面预订会议。我甚至听说过有人编造假的或模糊的会议标题，希望其他人会认为那是一个真实的会议。这是一个糟糕的变通办法，而且还不够。
解决办法应该是办公时间。你应该可以说“我周二和周四下午2点到5点有空开会，如果你想和我聊聊，那你就可以了。”在大多数公司，这样做会让你很烦人。这些公司不尊重深度工作。
安排会议应该会有点痛苦。你应该真的很想要它。你应该被迫质疑自己。这真的值得我不厌其烦地想出如何安排这次会议吗？或者会不会是一场异步讨论呢？办公时间和日历允许列表都有这个额外的好处。
note_en:
Does your company have a culture of letting everyone see each other’s calendars? Do people often schedule meetings whenever there are openings, without asking?
 If so, your calendar is a blocklist. The only time that isn’t available for someone to steal is time that’s already spoken for. This is a problem. A time slot that isn’t currently booked shouldn’t be free real estate. That’s my TIME! You can’t just take it without asking.
 Instead, your calendars should be an allowlist. You should say “if you want to talk to me, this is when you can” instead of “this is when you CAN’T.” You shouldn’t have to defend our time like it’s gold and your coworkers are pirates. You should just assume that it’s yours to spend how you see fit.
 Some people block time off to try to protect their calendars. They create big “GTD” blocks on their calendar and hope that nobody books meetings on top of them. I’ve even heard of people creating fake or vague meeting titles in hopes that others will assume there’s a real meeting at that time. This is a crappy workaround, and it isn’t enough.
 The solution should be office hours. You should be able to say say “I’m free for meetings from 2-5pm on Tuesdays and Thursdays, and if you want to talk to me then that’s when you can.” In most companies, doing that would make you an annoyance. Those companies don’t respect Deep Work.
 Scheduling meetings should be a little bit painful. You should have to really want it. You should be forced to question yourself.  Is this actually worth me going to the trouble of figuring out how to schedule this meeting? Or could it instead be an asynchronous discussion? Office hours and calendars-as-allowlists have this added benefit.
title: 您的日历应该是允许列表，而不是阻止列表
title_en: Your calendar should be an allowlist, not a blocklist

似乎每年都有一座或两座新的摩天大楼拔地而起，直插沃克斯豪尔的九棵榆树的天空。安德鲁·罗杰斯(Andrew Rogers)写道，现在可能很难想象，但在上个千年的最后三分之一，该地区的天际线几乎没有改变。
从1964年到1999年的35年间，沃克斯豪尔几乎每一处景观都被一座建筑占据，那就是九榆树冷库。它甚至不是最高的。
即使1975年出现了高得多(88米)的1号市场塔，它也几乎没有成功地分散人们对冷藏库的注意力。这个巨大的、混凝土的、无窗的、多年来一直是多余的巨型巨石，在很大程度上是沃克斯豪尔的地标，也是SW8近乎反乌托邦的晚期工业景观的象征。
在它生命的大部分时间里，它都是空的，或者如果不是完全空的话就被它的主人抛弃了。它通常不是空的，而是绝对不是空的。根据传说，它被用作巡游场地、表演空间、录音棚和魔鬼崇拜的寺庙。有人说有人死在那里，它出现在“斯威尼”的一集里。2这些事情可能是真的吗？肯定是都市神话。
但我们有些言过其实了。让我们几乎从头开始吧。
九榆树冷库在其生命中储存冰冷的东西不到一半的时间。它存放肉、鱼、黄油和奶酪15年，然后20年什么都没有。
它于1964年11月30日开放，3位于以前由南方大都会燃气厂占用的土地上，而南都会煤气厂又建在普莱斯的专利蜡烛公司的贝尔蒙特工厂的工地上。目前的居住者是圣乔治大厦和绿色玻璃、翼顶的圣乔治码头公寓。如果这些商店和废弃的冷藏室在一场丑陋的比赛中对决，很难说谁会赢。
不管怎样，冷库建成了，在这个过程中填满了沃克斯豪尔溪-埃夫拉河的最后遗迹。4.
“泰晤士报”报道说，“欧洲最现代化的冷库”的开业值得一提，它的所有者伦敦冷藏公司(联合渔业集团的一家公司)花费了100多万英镑来建造。它的容量为200万立方英尺，可容纳16000多吨食品5，在那里装卸货物的速度和效率比欧洲任何其他冷库都要快和高效。它的目的是为冷冻食品加工商和分销商储存产品。7个。
其中一个原因是该网站是可用的。天然气厂在1956年消失了，这个地方被用作长途汽车公园。有一种说法说，“这里的小偷市场很兴旺，从布伦瑞克住宅顶楼的窗户看着的警察仔细观察并记录了这些情况。”
这个位置有很好的交通连接-河流，公路和铁路。根据商业汽车的一份报告，两艘驳船可以在冷库90英尺的泰晤士河8号码头同时卸货，8辆卡车一次可以使用四个有盖的装卸区。该杂志在其关于冷库开业的报道中热情洋溢地说，卡车停机位使用了液压码头平地机，电动托盘卡车和其他机械辅助设备得到了广泛使用。
1965年，九榆树的大部分(包括新考文特花园市场和后来被分流的花卉市场)被铁路站场占据。今天，该地区的铁路历史几乎被遗忘了，但从1838年开始的10年里，该地区拥有自己非常宏伟的铁路终点站，这是从沃金和后来的南安普顿来的火车的终点。九榆树站坐落在九榆树巷(当时名为九榆树)的尽头，当时出现在旺兹沃斯路上，大约在迈尔斯街(而不是现在的巴里街)尽头对面的旺兹沃斯路上。1848年，这条线路在到达车站之前改道，通过沃克斯豪尔的一个新车站到达滑铁卢的新终点站。现在被排挤在一边的九榆树地区(字面意思)变成了一个巨大的铁路站场，120多年来，它被不同地用作车厢和马车制造厂、货运站和火车场。
当它在1965年建成时，冷藏库是由穿过九榆树巷到达它的队伍服务的，正如这张1967年左右的地图所显示的那样。
在这一点上，九榆树巷仍然与迈尔斯街以北的旺兹沃斯路相遇。估计在七十年代初兴建新考文特花园花市时，它已改道至现时的位置(柏里街对面)。
可悲的是，冷库的三重运输威胁地位是短暂的-铁路站场仅在两年后，即1967年关闭。
制冷技术的进步、航空运输的增加、内河运输的消亡似乎都是可能的因素。联合渔业的冷藏业务受到英国1973-75年经济衰退的严重影响。但是网站的价值肯定起到了很大的作用。事实上，联合渔业主席早在1973年就提出了很多建议，当时冷藏库开业不到10年：
向联合渔业的股东发布消息[…]。主席P.M.Tapscott先生提到建议在沃克斯豪尔大桥南侧发展泰晤士河临街，以及AF的九棵榆树冷藏室(占地1.6英亩)毗邻这个发展项目。因此，当局现正密切研究重新发展的可能性。11个。
伦敦冷库在冷库关闭后很快就剥离了自己的地盘。1980年11月，“泰晤士报”报道说，冷库和其他财产的出售合同已经交换了167万英镑的现金，交易截止日期为2月5日12日。
这就是九榆树冷藏店的事情开始变得真正有趣的时候。
为什么冷藏库花了20年才拆除？如果有房地产开发恐怖色情的观众，可能会有一整本关于它的书要写。我只想说，在早期，它涉及罗纳德·里昂(Ronald Lyon)，他可以被描述为一位有着有趣商业经历的五颜六色的房地产开发商。
里昂在埃夫拉选址(包括桥脚两侧的土地)的第一份提案破裂后获得了冷藏库。
这个由建筑师雅培·霍华德(Abbott Howard)设计的1.5亿美元的“绿色巨人”项目将包括100套豪华公寓，3万平方米的埃索办公空间，以及一个存放泰特雕塑收藏品的画廊。
然后出现了里昂，他的阿伦布里奇公司从当时的环境国务秘书迈克尔·赫塞尔廷那里获得了一项有争议的特别发展令。这项SDO实质上会允许阿伦布里奇的办公室计划粗暴地运行正常的规划程序。尽管有这种不公平的优势，里昂未能找到资金，该计划失败了。瑞士宝盛银行(Julius Baer&Amp；Co)持有该地块作为贷款担保，他们将其出售给塞缪尔地产13号，塞缪尔地产13号又将其出售给一个中东财团，后者随后进行了…。好吧，你明白了吧。正在进行的发展障碍之一似乎是兰贝斯区反对现在张开双臂欢迎的那种时髦的住宅计划。
到底花了20年时间才拆除冷藏库还不清楚，但其中一个因素似乎是拆除的成本。一位参与了政府在埃夫拉(Effra)遗址上建造新内政部的计划的人士回忆说，由于拆除成本的原因，冷藏库将在该计划的后期得到解决。
在经历了漫长而挥之不去的衰落之后，九榆树冷库终于(我想)在1999年走出了困境。谢天谢地，乔纳森·贝尔在身边，为子孙后代记录下了这一事件。
伦敦电影制片人在寻找“近乎反乌托邦的荒凉工业景观”时，只需看看“九棵榆树”就行了--甚至在它被遗弃之前。与巴特西发电站相比，冷藏室不那么老套，不那么标志性，更具异国情调，在理查德·伯顿(Richard Burton)主演的犯罪片“恶棍”(1971)和彼得·塞勒斯(Peter Sellers)主演的“九棵榆树的乐观主义者”(The乐观主义者)(1973)等电影中短暂地出现了背景。但它最激动人心的用途肯定是1976年的警察连续剧“斯威尼人”(The Sweeney)中名为“从寒冷中走进来”(The Sweeney)的那一集，该剧讲述了这场在冷藏室屋顶上的对话。
1979年冷藏店关闭后，最频繁的游客是男同性恋者，他们把它作为夜间巡游场地，便于在附近的皇家沃克斯豪尔酒馆或位于市场塔高层的市场酒馆度过一晚。多年来，冷藏室是许多恋人的卧室和游戏室，但以提供几乎相等的快乐和危险而臭名昭著-有时会带来致命的后果。
约翰(化名)是一位死里逃生但活着讲述故事的参观者：
“如果你运气不好，九榆树冷藏室是你在市场酒馆待了一晚后去的地方。你通过人行桥穿过九榆树巷(当时行人被要求在所有的沃克斯豪尔十字街主干道上导航)，来到墙左边的一个大门，这扇门现在仍然是布伦瑞克大厦的避难所，不受九榆树巷的影响。钢门有10英尺高，锁着，顶部有带刺的铁丝网，但一侧的缝隙被强行打开，你可以挤进去进入冷藏室的地面。那时候还没有工地保安这回事。
“从大门到大楼入口处大约有20米的步行距离，这只是混凝土上的一个很大的缺口-没有门。人们会站在入口处，这样他们就可以看到谁来了-如果你再往前走，那里就是一片漆黑。
“约会一般会在后面的大楼里进行，那里有各种各样的房间。一般来说，你唯一能看到的就是发光的烟头。有时人们用打火机找路。如果你回头看，你可以从外面的路灯看到门口，但除此之外什么也看不见。这是可怕的，但这是兴奋的一部分。
“当时不仅很黑，而且很危险，你必须知道自己在做什么。如果你在入口后不左转，你就有可能掉到40英尺深的坑里。这就是1990年5月的一个星期三晚上1点左右我做的事情。
“我晚上去了市场酒馆的皮革市场。我当时22岁，性欲旺盛，没有拔过牙，从头到脚都穿着迷恋物的全套橡胶装备，穿着20孔Doc Marten靴子和一件轰炸机夹克。我以前只去过冷藏室两三次，因为我觉得它太可怕了。我挤过大门--小心翼翼地不弄坏我珍贵的橡胶齿轮--然后走向大门。与已经在那里的一位朋友打了个简短的招呼后，我走了进去。然后我突然觉得“好笑”--这就是我今天所描述的。我以为我要晕倒了，但实际上我正从40英尺的高空坠落。但是因为当时很黑，所以我不知道这一点。我活了下来的一个原因是因为我的身体完全放松了，这要归功于我幸福的无知。
“我一定是昏过去了。当我转过身来时，我可以看到打火机在我头顶附近的坑顶附近，人们往里看我发生了什么事。我的朋友在上面，我记得他忧心忡忡地问道，“约翰！你的眼镜掉了吗？“。
“然后，一名救援者--我以前从未见过的人--几乎神奇地从附近的某个地方出现，把我抱了起来，不知何故把我抬出了大门。”我不知道是怎么回事。
“他把我带到他停在榆树街九号的车里。我的手严重受伤，正在大量出血，他说他必须清理一下，止血。他打开后备箱，一堆假发和衣服掉了出来--原来他是当天的主要变装皇后之一。他找到了他用来卸妆的厨房毛巾卷，给我洗干净，然后开车送我去医院。
“在那个时候，似乎每周的首都同性恋报纸都有一篇报道，在报道中，急救部的工作人员表达了他们对在冷藏室巡航的人的愚蠢感到多么恼火，所以我拒绝去医院，他转而把我带回了家。”几个小时后，我的室友--看到我所处的状态--迫使我去了丹麦山国王学院医院的急诊室，在那里我撒了谎，告诉他们我被车撞了。
“当时，考虑到我摔了一跤，我的伤似乎很轻。我右脚的一块骨头裂开了，我的手一团糟--有足球那么大--而且我的脖子酸痛。只是在后来的生活中，这种影响才变得更加明显。我脖子底部的椎间盘中有三个被压缩了，并且已经逐渐恶化，这意味着我有时会失去手臂的感觉。我得在某个时候动手术。
“几个月后，当我要参加四年制大学课程的期末考试时，我的右手还缠着绷带。因为我不会写字，所以我不可能带他们去。最后，大家同意我参加三次考试，把3000字的论文听写到磁带录音机里。我的成绩是2：2。
“我知道那天晚上带着生命逃出冷藏室是我的幸运。其他人没有。救了我的是我不知道自己在摔倒，可能是因为我有点醉了。我想我的靴子保护了我的脚和脚踝免受更大的伤害。当然，我被那个下班的变装皇后勇敢果断的行为所拯救。
“我确实回到了九榆树冷库，但只在白天去过一次，试图找到我的眼镜。从洞的边缘往下看令人毛骨悚然，我震惊地发现自己掉得有多远。从那以后，我就再也没有回来过。“。
1990年，前卫音乐家化工厂萌生了将废弃的冷库不仅作为录音棚，而且作为音乐的一部分的想法。
二人组阿什利·戴维斯和理查德·加隆创作的音乐和声音被描述为“催眠打击乐和实验/环境声音蒙太奇的平衡，混合着空灵的人声和偏执的评论”。1990年6月9日星期六，他们邀请萨克斯管演奏家菲奥娜·赛尔(Fiona Sail)和主唱平基·麦克卢尔(Pinkie Maclure)与他们一起在Nine Elms冷藏店创作了一些特别和独特的东西，结果就是冷藏室磁带。
我们当时正在制作的音乐被粗略地称为“工业”，我们有兴趣利用这么大的工业空间来为我们的录音提供氛围。
那时候还可以随便逛进去。我们白天去了，但一旦你离开一楼，那里是开着的，光线进来了，那就是一个相当可怕的地方。我特别记得菲奥娜穿过一扇门走进楼上一个巨大的空间，当时我们都在玩耍。当她的影子出现在门口时，萨克斯的响亮回声让我大吃一惊。
这个想法基本上是为了记录建筑本身的声音，平基发现她几乎可以在那里用自己的声音发出和弦，从建筑内部的延迟是如此漫长和持久。我们用便携式立体声录音机把一切都录了下来。每一种声音都是用声音、萨克斯管或我们在那里找到的金属和其他物品发出的。盒式磁带和后来发行的CD是由经过编辑的录音版本组成的，没有添加任何效果或其他处理，因此声音与在大楼内录制的完全相同。
理查德后来用照片和稍后拍摄的Super 8胶片合成了这段视频：
这四张令人回味的照片由马丁·皮克顿(Martin Picton)拍摄，用于宣传化工厂的冷藏磁带：
从dor.co.uk上可以买到冷藏磁带的CD，它捕捉到了这种即兴的音响表演的所有原始强度和诱惑力。
关于九榆树冷藏库的一个令人震惊和挥之不去的故事是，它是一个黑魔法、魔鬼崇拜、祭祀和狂欢的场所(多年来，它确实看到了比公平份额更多的狂欢)。
我可以证实，在80年代中期，这里发生了一些不寻常的事情。当时我是伦敦警察厅的一名警察，凌晨时分，一位匿名来电者把我们叫到那里，发现了一具身体。楼梯间确实有一个死人，我想他是从屋顶的活板门掉下来死的。然而，…。在搜查其中一层楼时，我们在手电筒的灯光下发现了一个相当可怕的房间，里面有一个装饰过的房间。墙上和柱子上有一张床、一个祭坛和各种束缚装置。其中一些是儿童尺寸的。唯一能描述它们的方式就像把人绑在空中的身体吊带。根据记忆，这个地方原来是一群寮屋居民使用的，他们占领了附近一个废弃的露台进行拍摄。不是我想看的那种电影。那天晚上确实是一个可怕的地方，我不知道调查的结果是什么，因为那天晚上我没有参与其中。可能是狂欢/电影/黑魔法布景，房间里有各种各样奇怪的东西。
事实上，魔鬼崇拜用具很可能是1985年在那里举行的一次不太成功的“事件”留下的，那次活动以“亵渎宗教的内容和意象”为特色。Rob La Frenais在Performance Magazine上写道：14。
刚开始的时候，所有的标志都是正确的。当我们在黄昏的时候穿过瓦砾，跳进一个臭气熏天的洞里时，一种怀旧的感觉，这个洞连接着我们上上下下的台阶，从那里可以看到来自四面八方的其他人，就像被雷达回波吸引到了大楼的中心。在安东尼奥尼的爆炸中，如果我被弹射到看不见的网球场景中，我不会感到惊讶。一旦进入，事情看起来也很有希望。一个洞穴般的地方，散发着香气，各种“神龛”散落在周围，困惑的参与者在最后一刻做准备。
从这一点开始，事情开始走下坡路。在自由自在地闲逛之后，我们都被赶回了接待室，组织者继续犯下了他们的一个大错误，那就是扼杀了可能出现的任何自发行为。这是为了组织我们进行一次“有导游的旅行”，由一位“大主教”以无可辩驳的演员般的嗓音进行，他将向我们介绍“大教堂”的各个方面。观众相当多，他们来参加的活动具有所有“边缘”活动的装饰品-似乎是非法进入的建筑，黑暗，亵渎神明(祭坛是一张大双人床)-立即开始对被一群戏剧学生赶来赶去表现出不满。居住在当地的资深极端主义行为艺术家伊恩·欣奇克利夫(Ian Hinchcliffe)来这里查看他的庄园里发生的事情，在退休到酒吧之前，他立即辱骂并砸碎了一个方便的灯具配件。组织者紧张地夺回了控制权，但夜晚，美妙的地方，美妙的布景都失去了。这一类型已经被劫持，并被发现不足。
下一期“表演杂志15”刊登了SW8的安迪·哈泽尔的一封信，他可能是组织者之一：
亲爱的Performance Magazine，前段时间，您和其他许多人一样，参加了九榆树冷库的演出，[…]。这是一个有组织的混乱之夜，停电，令人头疼的人和精神上的不景气。嗯，我只是想你可能会喜欢随函附上的作为纪念品。我从非洲回来，发现警察用斧头砍倒了我的前门，把我所有的财物翻了个底朝天，寻找邪恶的谋杀武器。假设它只是为了展示生活和艺术是如何密不可分地交织在一起的。至少“镜报”是这么认为的。
有没有可能大都会警察发现了一具身体和事发时的道具，把两个人和两个人放在一起，得出了五个人的结论？
为什么“冷藏室”会让人联想到。

A new skyscraper –  or two – thrusts itself up into the skies of Vauxhall-Nine Elms every year, it seems. It may be hard to imagine now, writes Andrew Rogers, but for the final third of the last millennium, the area’s skyline hardly changed at all.
  For 35 years between 1964 and 1999 almost every view of Vauxhall was dominated by one building – the Nine Elms Cold Store. And it wasn’t even the tallest.
 Even when the much taller (88m) Market Towers    1 came along in 1975, it barely succeeded in distracting the eye from the cold store. This giant, concrete, windowless, and for years redundant, monolith was very much Vauxhall’s landmark and a symbol of SW8’s almost dystopian-looking late-industrial landscape.
 For most of its life it stood empty, or if not quite empty then abandoned by its owners. It was often emphatically not empty. According to legend it was used as a cruising ground, a performance space, a recording studio, and a temple for devil worship. Some say people died in there, and that it featured in an episode of  The Sweeney.    2 Can these things possibly be true?’ Urban myths surely.
 But we’re getting ahead of ourselves. Let’s start almost at the beginning.
  The Nine Elms Cold Store stored cold things for less than half of its life. It held meat, fish, butter and cheese for 15 years then nothing for 20.
 It opened on 30 November 1964    3 on land previously occupied by the  South Metropolitan Gas Works which in turn had been built on the site of  Price’s Patent Candle Company‘s Belmont works. The current occupant is the St George Tower and the green-glass, wing-topped St George Wharf apartments. Were these to be pitted against the derelict cold store in an ugliness competition it’s difficult to say who would win.
 Anyway, the cold store was built, filling in Vauxhall Creek – the last vestige of the river Effra – in the process.    4
 The opening merited a mention in  The Times which reported that ‘Europe’s most modern cold store’ had cost its owners London Cold Storage Co (one of the Associated Fisheries Group of Companies) more than £1 million to build. With a capacity of two million cubic feet it could hold more than 16,000 tons of food    5 and goods could be loaded and unloaded there faster and more efficiently than at any other cold store in Europe.    6 Its purpose was to store produce for frozen-food processors and distributors.    7
  One reason was that the site was available. The gas works had disappeared in 1956 and the site was being used as a coach park.  According to one account, ‘Here a thieves’ market thrived, carefully observed and recorded by police officers watching from the top floor windows of  Brunswick House.’
  The location had excellent transport connections – river, road, and rail. Two barges could be unloaded simultaneously at the Cold Store’s 90ft Thames jetty    8 and eight lorries at a time could use the four covered loading bays, according to a report in  Commercial Motor.    9 ‘Hydraulic dock levellers are used at the lorry bays and electric pallet trucks and other mechanical aids are widely used,’ swooned the periodical in its report on the opening of the cold store.
 In 1965 most of Nine Elms (including the site of the New Covent Garden Market and the since-shunted flower market) was occupied by railway yards. Today, the area’s railway history is all but forgotten but for 10 years from 1838 the area boasted its very own and quite grand railway terminus which was the end of the line for trains coming in from Woking and later Southampton.  Nine Elms Station stood at the end of Nine Elms Lane (then just called Nine Elms) which at that time emerged onto the Wandsworth Road roughly opposite the end of Miles Street (not Parry Street, as now). In 1848 the line was diverted before it reached the station to the new terminus at Waterloo via a new station at Vauxhall. The now-sidelined (literally) Nine Elms area became a massive railway yard and for over 120 years served variously as a carriage and wagon works, a goods depot and a locomotive depot.
 When it was built in 1965 the Cold Store was served by lines which reached it by crossing Nine Elms Lane, as this map from around 1967 shows.
 At this point, Nine Elms Lane still met the Wandsworth Road just north of Miles Street. It was presumably rerouted to its current position (opposite Parry Street) in the early 1970s when New Covent Garden flower market was built.
 Sadly the Cold Store’s triple-transport-threat status was short-lived – the railway yard closed just two years later, in 1967.
   Advances in refrigeration, the increase in air transportation, the demise of river-based haulage seem likely factors. And Associated Fisheries’ cold storage business had been badly affected by the UK’s 1973–75 recession.    10 But the value of the site must have played a significant role. In fact, the Chairman of Associated Fisheries suggested so much as far back as 1973 when the Cold Store had been open for less than a decade:
 Giving news to shareholders of Associated Fisheries […] Mr P. M. Tapscott, chairman refers to the proposed development of the Thames frontage on the south side of Vauxhall Bridge and the fact that AF’s Nine Elms cold store, a site of 1.6 acres, adjoins this development. Possibilities of re-development are, therefore, being closely examined.    11
 London Cold Storage divested itself of the site pretty quickly after the Cold Store closed. In November 1980,  The Times reported that contracts had been exchanged on the sale of the cold store and other property for £1.67 million cash with completion due on February 5.    12
 Which is when things begin to get really interesting at the Nine Elms Cold Store.
  Why did it take 20 years for the Cold Store to be demolished? There’s probably a whole book to be written about it if there’s an audience for property development horror porn. Suffice to say that in the early days it involved Ronald Lyon, who could be described as a colourful property developer with an interesting business past.
 Lyon got his hands on the Cold Store after the first proposal for the Effra site (which included land on both sides of the bridgefoot) fell apart.
 The extraordinary 150m ‘Green Giant’ project designed by architects Abbott Howard would have included 100 luxury apartments, 30,000 square metres of office space earmarked for Esso, and a gallery to hold the Tate’s sculpture collection.
 Then along came Lyon, whose Arunbridge company was granted a controversial Special Development Order from the then Secretary of State for the Environment, Michael Heseltine. This SDO would essentially allow Arunbridge’s office scheme to run roughshod over normal planning procedures. Despite this unfair advantage, Lyon failed to find the funding and the scheme collapsed. The Swiss Bank Julius Baer & Co was holding the site as security against a loan and they sold it to Samuel Properties    13 who in turn sold it to a Middle Eastern consortium, who then… well, you get the picture. One of the ongoing barriers to development seems to have been the Borough of Lambeth’s objection to swanky residential schemes of the kind it now welcomes with open arms.
 Quite how it took two decades to knock the Cold Store down isn’t clear but one factor seems to have been the cost of demolition. One person involved in a government scheme to build a new Home Office on the Effra site recalls that the Cold Store was to be addressed late in the scheme due to  the cost of demolishing it.
 After a long, lingering decline, the Nine Elms Cold Store was finally put out of its misery in (I think) 1999. Thankfully Jonathan Bell was around to record the event for posterity.
    London film makers in search of ‘bleak industrial landscape bordering on dystopian’ needed to look no further than Nine Elms – even before it was abandoned. Less hackneyed, less iconic, and more alien than Battersea Power Station, the Cold Store made fleeting background appearances in films such as  Villain (1971), a crime film starring Richard Burton, and  The Optimists of Nine Elms (1973) with Peter Sellers. But the most thrilling use of it must surely be the 1976 episode of cop series  The Sweeney called ‘In From the Cold’, which featured this exchange on the very roof of the Cold Store.
   After the closure of the Cold Store in 1979 its most frequent visitors were gay men, who adopted it as a night-time cruising ground, handy for rounding off a night out at the nearby Royal Vauxhall Tavern or the Market Tavern which was housed in the Market Towers high-rise. The Cold Store was a bedroom and playroom to many liaisons over the years but was notorious for providing pleasure and danger in almost equal measure – sometimes with fatal consequences.
 One visitor who narrowly escaped death but lived to tell the tale is John (not his real name):
 “The Nine Elms Cold Store was where you went after a night at the Market Tavern if you didn’t get lucky. You crossed Nine Elms Lane via the footbridge (pedestrians were made to navigate all the Vauxhall Cross main roads that way back then) to a gate just to the left of the wall which still shelters Brunswick House from Nine Elms Lane today. The steel gate was 10 feet high, padlocked, and there was barbed wire across the top, but a gap had been forced open at one side through which you could squeeze to get in to the grounds of the cold store. There was no such thing as site security in those days.
 “It was about a 20-metre walk from the gate to the building’s entrance which was simply a big gap in the concrete – no doors. People would stand just inside the entrance so they could see who arrived – if you went any further in it was pitch black.
 “Assignations would generally take place further back in the building where there were various rooms. Generally, the only things you could see were glowing cigarette tips. Sometimes people used lighters to find their way around. If you looked back you could see the doorway from the street lights outside, but nothing else. It was scary but that was part of the excitement.
 “Not only was it dark but it was hazardous and you had to know what you were doing. If you didn’t turn left after the entrance you risked toppling down a 40 ft pit. Which is what I did at about 1am one Wednesday night in May 1990.
 “I’d been to the Market Tavern’s Market Leathers night. I was a horny 22-year-old, I hadn’t pulled and was head-to-toe in fetish-wear – full rubber gear with 20-hole Doc Marten boots and a bomber jacket. I’d only been to the Cold Store two or three times before because I found it too scary. I squeezed through the gate – being ultra-careful not to damage my precious rubber gear – and walked to the opening. After a brief hello to a friend who was already there, I walked on in. And then I very suddenly felt ‘funny’ – that’s how I describe it to this day. I thought I was fainting but actually I was falling 40 feet through the air. But because it was dark I didn’t know that. One reason I survived was because my body was completely relaxed thanks to my blissful ignorance.
 “I must have passed out. When I came round I could see lighters way above me around the top of the pit as people peered in to see what had happened to me. My friend was up there and I remember him asking with concern, but somewhat missing the point, ‘John! Did you lose your glasses?’
 “Then a rescuer – someone I’d never met before – appeared almost magically from somewhere close by, scooped me up and somehow carried me outside and back out the gate. I’ve no idea how.
 “He got me to his car which was parked on Nine Elms Lane. I’d badly damaged my hand which was bleeding profusely and he said he’d have to clean it up a bit and stop the bleeding. He opened the boot and a pile of wigs and dresses fell out – it turned out he was one of the main drag queens of the day. He found the kitchen towel roll he used for taking off his make-up, cleaned me up, and started driving me to hospital.
 “Now at that time it seemed as though every week’s Capital Gay newspaper contained a story in which Casualty staff expressed how pissed off they were with stupidity of people who went cruising in the Cold Store so I refused to go to hospital and he took me home instead. A few hours later my flatmate – seeing the state I was in – forced me to go to the A&E at King’s College Hospital in Denmark Hill where I lied and told them I’d been hit by a car.
 “At the time my injuries seemed minor considering the fall I’d taken. I’d chipped a bone in my right foot, my hand was a mess – the size of a football – and I had a sore neck. It was only in later life that the effects became clearer. Three of the discs at the base of my neck were compressed and have steadily deteriorated, meaning I sometimes lose feeling in my arms. I’ll have to have an operation at some point.
 “My right hand was still bandaged a few months later when I was due to sit the final exams for my four-year university course. There was no way I could take them because I couldn’t write. Eventually it was agreed that I would take three exams by dictating the 3,000-word essays into a cassette recorder. I got a 2:2.
 “I know that I was lucky to get out of the Cold Store that night with my life. Other people didn’t. What saved me was not knowing I was falling and it may have helped that I was a bit drunk. I think my boots protected my feet and ankles from greater injury. And, of course, I was saved by the brave and decisive actions of that off-duty drag queen.
 “I did go back to the Nine Elms Cold Store but only once and in the daytime to try and find my glasses. Looking down over the edge of the hole was terrifying and I was shocked to see just how far I’d fallen. I never returned after that.”
  In 1990, avant garde musicians  Chemical Plant hatched the idea of using the abandoned Cold Store not just as a recording studio, but as a part of the music.
 Duo Ashley Davies and Richard Gallon created music and sounds which have been described as ‘a balance of hypnotic percussion and experimental/ambient sound montages, mixed with ethereal vocals and paranoid commentaries’. They invited saxophonist Fiona Sail and vocalist Pinkie Maclure to join them at the Nine Elms Cold Store on Saturday 9 June 1990 to create something special and unique, and the result was  The Cold Store Tapes.
  The music we were making at the time was loosely termed ‘industrial’ and we were interested in using such a big industrial space to provide the atmosphere for our recordings.
 At that time it was still possible to just wander in. We went during the day but once you left the ground floor where it was open and light came in it was quite a spooky place. I particularly remember Fiona walking in through a door into one of the huge spaces upstairs while we were all playing. The loud echoing blast of the sax as her shadow appeared in the doorway gave me quite a start.
 The idea was essentially to record the sound of the building itself and Pinkie found that she could almost make chords with her voice there, the delay from the insides of the building being so long and sustained. We recorded everything on a portable stereo cassette recorder. Every sound was made either with voice, saxophone or pieces of metal and other objects we found there. The cassette and later CD releases were made up of edited versions of the recordings made with no effects or other treatments added so the sound is exactly as it was recorded inside the building.
 Richard later put together this video using photographs and Super 8 film shot at a later date:
    These four evocative photographs were taken by Martin Picton for use in promoting Chemical Plant’s  The Cold Store Tapes:
  The Cold Store Tapes are available on a CD which ‘captures this improvised acoustic performance in all of its raw intensity and allure’ from  dor.co.uk.
  One of the alarming and persistent stories about the Nine Elms Cold Store is that it was a venue for black magic, devil worship, sacrifices, and orgies (it did see more than its fair share of orgies over the years).
  I can confirm there was something out of the ordinary going on here in the mid 80s. I was a Met Policeman at the time and we got called there to a dead body by an anonymous caller in the early hours of the morning. There was indeed a dead guy on the stairwell, I think it turned out he had fallen through a trapdoor in the roof to his death. However… on searching one of the floors we found, by torchlight, which was pretty scary, a chamber that had been decorated. There was a bed, an altar and various restraining devices attached to the walls and pillars. Some of these were child sized. Only way to describe them was like body harnesses for pinning people up in the air. From memory it turned out the place was used by a group of squatters who had taken over a derelict terrace nearby for filming. Not the sort of film I would like to have seen. It was indeed a scary place that night, I’ve no idea what the result of the investigation was as I wasn’t involved past that night. Could have been an orgy/film/black magic set, there was all sorts of weird stuff in the room.
 In fact, that devil worship paraphernalia was probably left over from a not wholly successful ‘happening’ held there in 1985 which featured ‘religious-blasphemous content and imagery’. Rob La Frenais wrote about it in  Performance Magazine:    14
 At the start there were all the right signs. A sense of nostalgia as we picked our way across the rubble at dusk, to dive into a foul-smelling hole which connected with steps that led us up and up to an antechamber, from which it was possible to see others, coming from all directions, as if drawn by a radar echo to the central focus of the building. I would not have been surprised to have been catapulted in to the invisible tennis scene in Antonioni’s  Blow-up. Once inside, things looked promising too. A cavernous place, reeking of incense, with various ‘shrines’ scattered around and the confused participants making last-minute preparations.
 From this point things started to go downhill. After wandering around freely, we were all herded back into the antechamber, and the organisers proceeded to make their One Big Mistake which was to kill any spontaneity that might have been present. This was to organise us into a ‘guided tour’ conducted by an ‘archbishop ‘ with an unmistakeable actorly voice, who was to introduce us to each aspect of the ‘cathedral’. The audience, which was sizeable, and who had come to participate in what had all the trappings of a ‘marginal’ event, – a seemingly illegally entered building, darkness, blasphemy (the altar was a large double bed) – immediately started showing resentment about being herded about by a bunch of drama students. The veteran extremist performance artist, Ian Hinchcliffe, who lives locally, and was here to check out events on his manor, immediately hurled abuse and smashed a handy light fitting before retiring to the pub. The organisers nervously regained control, but the evening, wonderful place, wonderful setting was lost. The genre had been hijacked, and was found wanting.
 The next edition of  Performance Magazine    15 featured a letter from an Andy Hazell of SW8, presumably one of the organisers:
 Dear Performance Magazine, Some time ago, you like many others attended the performance in Nine Elms Cold Store, […] a night of organised chaos, power failures, headbangers and spiritual bad times. Well, I just thought you might like the enclosed as a memento. I returned from Africa to find the police had axed down my front door and turned all my worldly goods inside out hunting for evil murder weapons. Suppose it just goes to show how life and art are inextricable entwined. At least the  Mirror thinks so.
 Is it possible that the Metropolitan Police had found a body and the props from the happening, put two and two together and made five?

APL被设计成如此富有表现力，以至于整个程序都可以写在一个页面上，并且程序员可以掌握它们的结构。这个Prezzo为APL巧妙地提供了理由，如果没有它，我就不会写这篇博客文章。一定要读一读--它让我大吃一惊。

所以基本上就是把电子表格变成商业程序。(你们中的一些人会知道，这个话题长期以来一直与我息息相关。)。

Well this is mine — the BEAM, which already has  Prolog-y (Erlang),  Algol-y (Elixir) and  Lisp-y (LFE) languages needs an  APL-y language wut looks like the pic at the top of this post.
 APL — which stands for  Another Programming Language, imagine the brass neck of that, eh? — is an old 60s language designed to be expressive.
  Good question — lets start with why before we tuck in. The only reason to write a new programming language is to be able to do things better/faster.
 Way back in the day I was hired at Basho and had to do their coding challenge. As the company is bankrupt now, lets see it:
 A version vector is a concise representation of events for tracking changes to a data item in a distributed system. You can read more about them here ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Version_vector), and here ( http://haslab.wordpress.com/2011/07/08/version-vectors-are-not-vector-clocks/). Attached is a file. On each line is a two-tuple containing two version vectors {VC1, VC2}. The version vector is modeled as a list of two-tuples, VC=[{ActorId, CountInteger}]. The first entry is an actor in the system, in this case an 8 byte Erlang binary <<A,B,C,D,E,F,G,H>>. The second entry is a positive integer that denotes the latest event by that actor that the clock summarizes. Version vector A descends version vector B if every event summarized in B is also in A. Version Vector A and B are equal if A descends B and B descends A, A and B are concurrent if A summarizes events not seen by B and B summarizes events not seen by A. For the provided file, write a program that outputs a row in a table for each pair of vectors such that each column outputs true or false, where A is the first clock in the tuple, and B is the second. A descends B | B descends A | A equals B | A is concurrent with B for example: {[{<<199,214,110,13,247,118,16,223>>,1}],[{<<0,88,3,113,66,198,7,52>>,1},{<<199,214,110,13,247,118,16,223>>,1}]} generates false | true | false | false as the first version vector is an ancestor of the second version vector. Program in the language of your choice. You may use external libraries of your choice. Please provide us with the program, instructions on how to run it, and the resulting output. Please email us if you need further clarification. Good luck!
 My solution is  online now — basically 500 raw lines of code in total, including tests. So what would it look like in APL? Something like this (forgive me the gods of APL, for I is a noob):
 Vector1 ← 3 2 ⍴ 'a' 41 'b' 42 'c' 43 Vector2 ← 3 2 ⍴ 'a' 12 'c' 43 'd' 99 IsSameShape ← {^/((⍴⍺) = (⍴⍵))} ... (need an If here) IsEqual ← {+/ (⍺[;1] = ⍵[;1]) ^ (⍺[;2] = ⍵[;2]) } Actors1 ← Vector1[;1] Actors2 ← Vector2[;1] Shared1 ← Vector1[(Actors1 ∊ Actors2) / ⍳⍴Actors1;2] Shared2 ← Vector2[(Actors2 ∊ Actors1) / ⍳⍴Actors2;2] IsUnshared ← ^/(Actors1 ∊ Actors2) ... (need an If here) DoesDescend ← ^/ ((Shared1 ⌈ Shared2) = Shared1)
 (you can’t do flow control in the in-browser REPL I wrote this in, sooooo…. This version is also probably a bit too long and real APLer could do it shorter.)
   APL is designed to be so expressive that whole programmes can be written on a single page and their structure grasped by the programmer. This  prezzo makes the case for APL ably and without it I wouldn’t have written this blog post. Do read it — it blew my mind.
 The coding example is a key part of CRDTs (Convergent Replicated Data Types) and a swatch at one of those CS papers might give a clue as to why it is so short in APL, it all set-based maths:
  APL is designed to be expressive — and exposes many set operations to the developer — it is quick to write CRDT-like things because it is designed that way. Once you understand the seemingly bizarre syntax it is actually a very simple language.
 Bear in mind my APL experience is reading the  manual for 4 hours on a flight, and  programming for another 4 so: 1 days experience tops.
 By comparison when I did it in Erlang I had 11 years full time under my belt.
  Riak has a number of other gnarly problems which have elegant statements of requirement but whose implementations have considerable accidental complexity when written in Erlang.
  preflists — where to do to to read data from the cluster, particularly for stuff like rack-awareness and guaranteed writes to multiple data centres and stuff
  A core technique in APL is taking two sets of information and generating an boolean matrix with them, and then apply a set of rules to reduce that boolean matrix to a single boolean — a decision, yes/no. Essentially it is a business rules language.
 My dear friend Mary Kane informs me that when she left school to join Irish Life Insurance she was trained as an APL programmer — taking sets of actuarial tables, apply an individuals data to them and reducing the resulting boolean matrices to business decisions, buy/sell, pricing, calculate returns, etc, etc.
 This pattern will be familiar to spreadsheet users. Spreadsheets as a business function are largely large sets of static data which are mapped to boolean matrices in the presence of scenario data and then reduced to decisions.
 The famous paper on what functions spreadsheet users actually use makes this very clear. They dumped every spreadsheet at a large company and a government department and then finger-printed function use in them. The results are stark:  sum,  vlookup and  if for the win:
  So basically turning spreadsheets into business programmes then. (A subject that some of you will know has long been close to my heart.)
   Sometimes you are just pregnant with a whole programme — you can see its implementation suddenly, as from a blue sky, and you just need to vom it out through your fingers — so it is with this APL dialect.
 But I really have too much on my plate with a new job and all to do such a thing. If anyone fancies it I could write up how I would do it ;-)

在上个月宣布PS5和Xbox Series X上NBA2K21的建议零售价高于正常水平70美元后，出版商Take-Two现在表示，提高价位可能不是其未来下一代游戏机游戏的标准。
首席执行官施特劳斯·泽尔尼克(Strauss Zelnick)在周一晚间的财报电话会议上表示，我们将明确宣布按标题定价。我只想观察一下，虽然成本大幅增加，但已经很长一段时间没有一线涨价了。
这是一个合理的观点：高端游戏的功能上限上一次上调是在2006年左右，当时随着Xbox360和PS3的推出，标准从50美元上涨到60美元。经通胀调整后，大预算游戏的最高要价从未像现在这样低，而开发成本也从未像现在这样高过。
尽管有这些压力，泽尔尼克还是不愿意把70美元定为他公司事实上的新标准定价。他说：我们重新采用这个价位，以防我们认为质量不仅支持它，而且要求它。生产成本大大提高了。但最重要的是，消费者体验比以往任何时候都更加强劲。我完全相信NBA2K21将会是非同寻常的，所以我不认为会有任何担忧。
Zelnick的评论是对该公司在7月份发表的一份不那么具体、更温和的声明的补充：2K对其游戏的建议零售价是为了代表所提供的价值，2K的一名代表当时表示。几乎无穷无尽的重放价值，以及许多新的添加和改进只能在下一代游戏机上实现，我们相信我们最新的建议零售价公平地代表了NBA 2K21的价值。&#34；
虽然它还处于游戏机过渡周期的早期阶段，但还没有其他发行商公开追随Take-Two进入70美元的游戏定价范围，即使是作为一个试验气球。相比之下，育碧首席执行官伊夫·吉利莫特在最近的一次财报电话会议上明确表示，2020年的圣诞游戏将以目前60美元的标准价格出售。
微软(Microsoft)的菲尔·斯宾塞(Phil Spencer)在最近接受“华盛顿邮报”(The Washington Post)采访时略微回避了70美元的游戏定价问题，没有对该公司未来自己的第一方游戏定价发表评论。
他告诉“华盛顿邮报”：“作为一个行业，我们可以为任何我们想要定价的东西定价，客户将决定对他们来说合适的价格是多少。”“我并不反对人们为游戏设定一个新的价格点，因为我知道每个人都会根据自己的业务需求做出自己的决定。但今天的游戏玩家拥有比以往更多的选择。归根结底，我知道客户可以控制他们支付的价格，我相信这个系统。“
尽管出版商对此保持沉默，但一些行业观察人士认为，在这一点上，新的、更高的价位几乎是不可避免的。
分析公司IDG的首席执行官大佐木义夫(Yoshio Osaki)上个月告诉GamesIndustry.biz，IDG与所有主要游戏发行商都有合作，我们的渠道调查显示，其他发行商也在探索提高某些特许经营权的下一代定价。虽然开发和出版的成本上升了，其他娱乐垂直市场的价格也大幅上升，但下一代软件的价格并没有反映出这些增长。59.99美元到69.99美元甚至不能完全覆盖其他成本的增加，但确实使其朝着正确的方向发展。
最终，这可能取决于游戏玩家用他们的钱包投票来决定每款游戏额外的10美元是否超过了某种消费临界点。“典型的游戏机玩家每年只购买几款完整的游戏，所以虽然10美元的涨价可能会减少利润率，但我也怀疑更多的游戏玩家会一直等到套装游戏或数字商店的价格降至60美元或50美元。”IDC分析师刘易斯·沃德(Lewis Ward)上个月告诉汤姆的指南。“因此，主要影响可能是将部分购买力有限的游戏玩家的销售推迟到较晚的日期。”
沃德继续说：“我们将拭目以待，看看这些游戏机上完整游戏的标准价格是不是(70美元)，但我的直觉告诉我，除非游戏玩家强烈反对，否则它很快就会成为常态。”

Google Play Music has been given the death sentence by Google, and today the company  has announced a bit more detail about how its execution will be carried out. The main message from today's blog post is "back up your music now," as Google says it will wipe out all Google Music collections in December 2020.
 We've known  for a while that the shutdown would be sometime in 2020, but for most regions, Google has now narrowed it down to "October." Here's the full timeline:
 Late August—Users will no longer be able to upload or download music through Music Manager. Pre-orders and purchases will be shut down.
  October—Global streaming shutdown. The Google Music app and website will cease to be.
 At the time of the streaming shutdown, the app will have been showing shutdown messages for about five months. If a user has somehow missed all of those, two months with no streaming at all will hopefully be enough to get them to research what happened to Google Music.
 Saving your music collection from deletion is not difficult; just go to  music.youtube.com/transfer and click a few buttons to start the YouTube Music transfer process. The process  is actually painless, and your Google Music account will continue to work even after the transfer. If you decide you don't want to use YouTube Music, you'll still have access to a ton of download options later, without the looming threat of the Google Music deletion.
 A copy of your files isn't hard to get, either. The  Google Music Manager is a Windows and Mac application that can upload music or download your entire music collection with a few clicks, but like Google said, it will stop working soon. The other option is  Google Takeout, which will wrap your entire music collection in a zip file and send you a download link. The processing for this can take hours. Whichever option you choose, make sure you do something before December because, after that, there will be no way to recover your music.
 Google Play Music has been around  since 2011 and let users upload thousands of songs to the Internet, for free, for streaming playback on most other devices. It's been the primary way to play music on the Google Home smart speakers, and it offered music purchases, monthly streaming radio, and podcasts. Google Music has been neglected for years, though, and  like the company often does, Google decided to make a second, competing music streaming service instead of maintaining the first service. That second service is YouTube Music, which is now Google's favored music app. The merger between the two was  originally announced in 2018, and now it's finally happening.
 YouTube Music places an emphasis on music videos, as you can guess from the name, and the app has a more modern design. YouTube Music awkwardly blends together your entire 15-year YouTube activity history with your music collection, tossing any "liked" videos and subscriptions that have been algorithmically been flagged as "music" into your collection, and mixing together your YouTube playlists and Google Music playlists. There is no way to stop this.
 YouTube Music seems designed to drive up Google's subscription numbers and really only seems useful for people who want to pay the monthly streaming license fee. The app does away with music purchases and  won't even let you stream your own music to your Google Home speakers without paying the monthly fee. It's a big downgrade from Google Music, which offered more functionality to people who purchased music.

note_en:
Today, Firefox is introducing Enhanced Tracking Protection (ETP) 2.0, our next step in continuing to provide a safe and private experience for our users. ETP 2.0 protects you from an advanced tracking technique called   redirect tracking, also known as  bounce tracking. We will be rolling out ETP 2.0 over the next couple of weeks.
 Last year we  enabled ETP by default in Firefox because  we believe that understanding the complexities and sophistication of the ad tracking industry should not be required to be safe online. ETP 1.0 was our first major step in fulfilling that commitment to users. Since we enabled ETP by default, we’ve blocked 3.4 trillion tracking cookies. With ETP 2.0, Firefox brings an additional level of privacy protection to the browser.
 Since the introduction of ETP, ad industry technology has found other ways to track users: creating workarounds and new ways to collect your data in order to identify you as you browse the web. Redirect tracking goes around Firefox’s built-in third-party cookie-blocking policy by passing you through the tracker’s site  before landing on your desired website. This enables them to see where you came from and where you are going.
  With ETP 2.0, Firefox users will now be protected against these methods as it checks to see if cookies and site data from those trackers need to be deleted every day. ETP 2.0 stops known trackers from having access to your information, even those with which you may have inadvertently visited. ETP 2.0 clears cookies and site data from tracking sites every 24 hours.
 Sometimes trackers do more than just track. They may also offer services you engage with, such as a search engine or social network. If Firefox cleared cookies for these services we’d end up logging you out of your email or social network every day, so we don’t clear cookies from sites you have interacted with in the past 45 days, even if they are trackers. This way you don’t lose the benefits of the cookies that keep you logged in on sites you frequent, and you don’t open yourself up to being tracked indefinitely based on a site you’ve visited once. To read the technical details about how this works, visit our  Security Blog post.
 What does this all mean for you? You can simply continue to browse the web with Firefox. We are doing more to protect your privacy, automatically. Without needing to change a setting or preference, this new protection deletes cookies that use workarounds to track you so you can rest easy.

积分计划是其他信用卡的“现金返还”服务的替代方案，后者立即奖励用户现金，他们可以保留或使用到下一张账单上。取而代之的是，Current的积分将在用户的账户下累积到一定的门槛，然后可以1美元兑100分的汇率兑换现金。它们还可以用于订阅。
目前，积分只适用于Current自己的会员订阅-该服务提供每月5美元的高级服务-但在未来，该公司设想使用积分来支付各种各样的订阅服务。
Current在发布时表示，大约50%的用户群生活在离报价2英里的范围内，但它正在努力将这一数字提高到100%。此外，即使在大流行期间，Current的用户也倾向于在他们所在的城市外出走动，因为大多数人(约80%)被归类为“基本工作者”。这包括那些在物流相关领域工作的人，如沃尔玛、亚马逊、Insta、DoorDash、Uber和Lyft，以及护士、军队和政府工作人员。
因为他们的工作，他们更有可能外出加油或在餐厅就餐，在那里他们可以很容易地获得积分。例如，目前估计，仅购买天然气一项，其成员每年就可以节省165美元的现金返还。
该公司表示，该公司是美国第一家推出积分奖励计划的新银行。尽管许多美国信用卡都提供积分或现金返还计划，但借记卡用户的庞大市场通常被忽视。(有几种基于奖励的借记卡，但为数不多)。
现任创始人兼首席执行官斯图尔特·索普(Stuart Sopp)解释说：“使用借记卡的人通常生活在一张又一张薪水上，而他们的钱要少得多。”他说，Current主要希望改善这些用户的财务状况，因为这是公司的核心使命。
然而，该计划也将让Current在越来越多的另类银行应用程序中脱颖而出，这些应用程序开始看起来都一样，这要归功于免费银行、免费现金取款和现代移动预算工具等消费者友好型功能的基线。
索普指出：“如果这意味着与Varo、Chime、Square和Venmo相比，在一个日益拥挤的市场中，用户认为我们更有价值，这是很有竞争力的。”他说：“我们非常自豪地伸出头来说，我们是第一家也是唯一一家提供积分的金融科技挑战者银行。”
随着时间的推移，积分计划还将有助于为Current创造额外的收入，因为它在银行和商家之间建立了一种关系-随着Current扩大其产品线，这一点可能会被证明是有价值的。
目前，Current正在利用几个未披露的第三方来帮助推动其积分计划，并结合内部努力-后者专注于让更大的品牌上岗。随着时间的推移，随着积分计划的发展，Current希望其商业合作伙伴将支付特权，让他们的优惠出现在最有可能兑换它们的用户面前。
索普说，这将不涉及共享用户的个人数据，而是将重点放在更合适地向最终用户提供优惠上。例如，一家餐厅的报价可能会出现在午餐时间左右。优惠也可以更精确的地理位置，在选择的基础上，所以当你走进商店时，你会得到一个关于优惠的提醒。
积分计划现在正在向Current的130万会员推出，既有基本的(免费的)，也有高级的(付费的)。目前的用户加在一起，到目前为止已经在手机银行存入了超过10亿美元。

The points program is an alternative to other credit cards’ “cashback” offerings, which reward users immediately with cash they can keep or apply to their next bill. Instead, Current’s points will accumulate under a user’s account to certain thresholds, then can be redeemed for cash at a rate of 100 points per dollar. They can also be used for subscriptions.
 At the moment, the points can be applied only to Current’s own membership subscription — the service offers a Premium tier for $5 per month — but further down the road, the company envisions using points to pay for a wide variety of subscription services.
   At launch, Current says around 50% of its user base lives within 2 miles of an offer, but it’s working to get that number to 100%. In addition, Current’s users tend to be out and about in their city, even amid the pandemic, as the majority (around 80%) are classified as “essential workers.” This includes those who work in logistics-related fields, like Walmart, Amazon, Instacart, Doordash, Uber, and Lyft, as well as nurses, military, and government workers.
 Because of their jobs, they’re more likely to be out getting gas or eating at restaurants, where they could easily gain points. Current estimates its members will save $165 per year in cash back just from their gas purchases alone, for example.
 The company is the first neobank to roll out a points-based rewards program in the U.S., it says. Though plenty of U.S. credit cards offer points or cashback programs, the large market of debit card users is typically ignored. (There are  a few rewards-based debit cards, but they’re few and far between).
 “People who use debit typically live paycheck to paycheck and have far less money,” explains Current founder and CEO, Stuart Sopp. He says Current primarily wants to improve these users’ financial outcomes, as that’s the company’s core mission.
 However, the program will also allow Current to stand out among a growing number of alternative banking apps that are starting to all look the same thanks to a baseline of consumer-friendly features like no-fees banking, free cash withdrawals, and modern mobile budgeting tools, among other things.
 “If it means competitively — compared to Varo, Chime, Square and Venmo — that users in an increasingly crowded market see there’s more value with us, then that’s great,” notes Sopp. “We’re very proud to stick our head out and say, we’re the first and only  fintech   challenger bank to offer points,” he says.
  The points program, over time, will also help to generate additional revenue for Current as it establishes a relationship between the bank and merchants — something that could prove valuable as Current expands its product line-up.
 At the moment, Current is leveraging several undisclosed third-parties to help power its points program, combined with internal efforts — the latter focused on onboarding the larger brands. Over time, as the points program grows, Current hopes its merchant partners will pay for the privilege of having their offers surfaced to those users who are most likely to redeem them.
 Sopp says this wouldn’t involve sharing users’ personal data, but rather would focus on targeting offers more appropriately to end users. For instance, an offer for a restaurant may appear around lunch time. Offers could also be more precisely geolocated, on an opt in basis, so you’ll get an alert to an offer as you walk in a store.
 The points program is rolling out now to Current’s 1.3 million members, both Basic (free) and Premium (paid). Combined, Current users have deposited over $1 billion to date in the mobile bank.

欧盟委员会表示，它有90个工作日来就收购做出决定-因此到2020年12月9日。
欧盟委员会执行副总裁玛格丽特·维斯特格(Margrethe Vestager)负责欧盟的竞争政策和数字战略，她在一份声明中评论称：“未来几年，欧洲消费者对可穿戴设备的使用预计将大幅增长。”这将与通过这些设备产生的数据的指数增长齐头并进。这些数据提供了有关这些设备用户的生活和健康状况的关键洞察力。我们的调查旨在确保谷歌对交易导致的通过可穿戴设备收集的数据的控制不会扭曲竞争。“。
谷歌(Google)对欧盟遏制其雄心的回应是，其设备和服务主管在一篇博客文章中试图为这笔交易辩护，辩称这将刺激创新并导致竞争加剧。
谷歌副总裁里克·奥斯特罗进一步宣称：“这笔交易涉及的是设备，而不是数据。”
这家科技巨头早在去年11月就宣布希望进入Fitbit的数据集，当时它宣布计划以21亿美元全现金收购这家可穿戴设备制造商。
几个月后，首席执行官桑达尔·皮查伊(Sundar Pichai)正因“帮助破坏互联网上的匿名性”等行为而受到国内立法者的指责。去年本已喧闹的反垄断鼓声在大型科技公司周围敲打，现在已经变成了一场充满激情的摇滚节，因此围绕科技公司收购的情绪音乐可能最终会发生变化。
自从谷歌(Google)计划收购Fitbit的消息传出后，整个欧洲都引发了对这笔交易的担忧-消费者团体、隐私监管机构以及竞争和技术政策专家都敲响了警钟，担心这家广告科技巨头可能会吞并一家设备制造商，并在此过程中帮助自己获取一系列敏感的消费者健康数据。
数字隐私权组织隐私国际(Privacy International)一直在敦促监管机构不要橡皮图章地批准这笔交易。该组织辩称，此次收购不仅会挤压新兴数字健康市场的竞争，也会挤压可穿戴设备的竞争，还会减少“谷歌目前在消费者(现有和未来的Fitbit用户)可用的隐私选择方面所面临的微不足道的竞争压力，导致隐私标准上的竞争变得更少，从而使消费者的隐私保护进一步恶化”。
噪音如此之大，以至于谷歌已经播放了“我们承诺不会…”的曲子。这张卡是数据挖掘技术巨头们的最爱。(通常在几年后，他们会说一句“我们抓到你了”的小丑--因为他们继续做他们完全不会做的事情。)。
也就是说，Fitbit从一开始就声称用户的“健康和健康数据不会用于谷歌广告”。就像WhatsApp说Facebook收购它们时什么都不会改变一样。(呃)。
上个月，路透社(Reuters)在一篇“独家”报道中重新讨论了这一让步，报道援引“知情人士”的话说，这些人显然告诉路透社，如果谷歌承诺不使用Fitbit数据投放广告，这笔交易可能会被否决。
目前尚不清楚其新闻报道的泄密来源，但路透社还引用了谷歌一位女发言人的话-她进一步声称：“在整个过程中，我们一直清楚地承诺，我们不会在谷歌广告中使用Fitbit健康数据，我们有责任为人们提供选择和控制他们的数据。”
最终，谷歌承诺用Fitbit数据表现自己，这一引人注目的承诺并未阻止欧盟监管机构介入更仔细地审视竞争问题--这恰恰是它应该做的。
事实上，鉴于目前人们对科技巨头的市场力量以及广告科技巨头谷歌(Google)专门攫取消费者健康数据宝库的担忧程度，全面调查是监管机构最起码应该做的事情。
如果说数字政策历史在过去十年+(以及数据方面)显示了什么，那就是魔鬼总是在细节中。此外，数字市场的快节奏可能意味着，竞争威胁可能只是一个微小的支点，距离实现只有一小步之遥。伤害理论显然需要更新，以考虑到数据挖掘技术社交平台巨头。欧盟委员会知道这一点-这就是为什么它正在咨询赋予自己更多权力，以解决数字市场中的小费问题。但它也需要灵活运用目前拥有的权力。比如展开适当的调查，而不是兴高采烈地挥舞着科技巨头的交易。
反垄断可能是本月科技巨头们关注的焦点-在上个月国会小组委员会的大对决中，美国立法者几乎向数字“强盗大亨”宣战。但也值得注意的是，欧盟竞争监管机构-尽管他们关于适当监管数字领域的言论大肆宣传-但尚未阻止一起数字技术合并。
欧盟委员会在今天的一份新闻稿中写道：“欧盟委员会担心，拟议中的交易将增加谷歌本已可以用来对其服务和显示的广告进行个性化处理的海量数据，从而进一步巩固谷歌在在线广告市场的市场地位。”
在对该交易进行初步评估后，欧盟监管机构表示，他们对(强调他们的)感到担忧：
交易对在线搜索和展示广告服务供应的影响(分别在互联网搜索引擎的结果页或其他互联网页面上出售广告空间)。
以及“提供‘广告技术’服务(用于促进数字广告的程序化销售和购买的分析和数字工具)”。
“通过收购Fitbit，谷歌将获得(I)Fitbit维护的有关其用户健康状况的数据库；以及(Ii)开发与Fitbit类似的数据库的技术，”欧盟委员会进一步指出。
“在欧盟委员会审查交易的这个阶段，通过手腕佩戴的可穿戴设备收集的数据似乎是在线广告市场的一项重要优势。通过增加谷歌在通过其搜索引擎提供的广告个性化方面的数据优势，并在其他网页上显示广告，竞争对手将更难与谷歌的在线广告服务相匹敌。因此，这笔交易将提高谷歌竞争对手获得这些服务的进入和扩张门槛，最终损害广告商和出版商的利益，因为它们将面临更高的价格，选择更少。“。
欧盟委员会认为，谷歌在几乎所有欧洲经济区(EEA)国家的在线搜索广告服务供应方面占据主导地位；在大量EEA国家(特别是非社交网络展示广告)的在线广告展示服务供应方面拥有“强大的市场地位”，在EEA的广告技术服务供应方面拥有“强大的市场地位”。
当谷歌考虑是否会通过吸收Fitbit数据获得不公平的竞争优势时，所有这些都将成为其考虑的依据。(维斯特格近年来还针对这家科技巨头发布了一系列反垄断执法措施，针对安卓(Android)、AdSense和谷歌购物(Google Shopping)。)。
“Fitbit和谷歌的数据库和功能在数字医疗领域的结合所产生的影响，该领域在欧洲仍处于初级阶段”
“一旦谷歌拥有Fitbit，它是否有能力和动机降低竞争对手的可穿戴设备与谷歌Android智能手机操作系统的互操作性？”
这家科技巨头已经向欧盟监管机构提供了一个具体的让步，希望让Fitbit Buy变得绿灯-欧盟委员会指出，它上个月提交了旨在解决担忧的承诺。
谷歌建议建立一个数据竖井，以保存通过Fitbit可穿戴设备收集的数据，并表示这些数据将与谷歌内部的任何其他数据集分开保存(包括声称出于广告目的将受到限制)。然而，欧盟委员会对谷歌的提议表示怀疑，写道，它“认为谷歌提出的数据竖井承诺不足以明确打消现阶段对交易影响的严重疑虑”。
“除了其他原因，这是因为数据竖井补救措施没有涵盖谷歌将因这笔交易而访问的所有数据，对于广告目的将是有价值的，”该公司补充道。
谷歌在其博客文章中提到了这个数据竖井，声称：“我们从一开始就很清楚，我们不会在谷歌广告中使用Fitbit的健康和健康数据。我们最近提出就我们对Fitbit数据的使用向欧盟委员会做出具有法律约束力的承诺。正如我们对所有产品所做的那样，我们将让Fitbit用户选择查看、移动或删除他们的数据。我们将继续支持我们和其他公司产品的广泛连通性和互操作性。“。
“我们很感激有机会与欧盟委员会合作，制定一种方法来满足消费者对其可穿戴设备的期望。我们相信，通过与Fitbit的专家团队密切合作，并结合我们在人工智能、软件和硬件方面的经验，我们可以为世界各地的人们制造令人信服的设备。“
